0.00.text:
>> GIROUARD: All righty. Had I known what
we would see there, I'm not sure I would have

5.19.text:
volunteered to be next in the agenda. And
I hate to feel like I'm the one who has to

15.13.text:
bring you back to "Earth." But thank you.
That was fun and interesting. We're gonna

20.74.text:
move on to our next section. We are gonna
bring some of the senior engineering and research

26.33.text:
and development leadership for all of Google,
not just the Enterprise parts. People that

32.69.text:
lead all of the technical development and
engineering research efforts at the company.

38.08.text:
Obviously, well-known figures inside Google
and ones who have had enormous impact across

42.56.text:
the industry. So let me introduce now Vint
Cerf--Oh, let me do it in order since they're

47.71.text:
in order. Here comes Vint Cerf, our chief
internet evangelist. Jeffrey Huber...SVP of

53.81.text:
engineering, and Alan Eustace, our SVP of
engineering and research at Google. Welcome.

63.95.text:
Welcome, gentlemen.
>> CERF: Thank you. I have a few questions,

67.67.text:
but I want to encourage you, starting now-ish--because
I'll be happy to intersperse questions from

72.61.text:
the audience. So I ask you to queue up. And
the one thing I'll add to the Q&A session

76.04.text:
prior is I would ask that you say your name
and what company you're from when you ask

81.18.text:
a question, just in the interest of, you know,
transparency and such. So feel free. But anyway,

86.78.text:
thanks, gentlemen. Great to have you here.
A great audience of CIOs and IT professionals

92.04.text:
and lots of others. So I'm gonna just open
up with a few questions, some of which I know

97.81.text:
some of the answers to. But I'll start with
Alan. I joined the company just over six years

103.29.text:
ago. It was a much smaller company then. Alan
joined the company far before then, so he

107.40.text:
has seen fairly enormous growth here. But
one thing I just want to ask Alan is what

113.89.text:
are some of the accomplishments that you've
seen at Google in your time here that you

118.03.text:
are most proud of, if you look back and reflect?
>> EUSTACE: These are the questions--Well,

123.99.text:
first, I'm Alan Eustace, and I work for Google.
Just--You know, there's just a lot of things

131.12.text:
that I'm very proud of. I feel like the search,
and especially the universal search, bring

135.43.text:
together, you know, images and, uh--Images,
Web--huge Web. You know, billions and billions

142.39.text:
of pages of, you know, video, you know, news,
all these kinds of things. I think doing that

147.66.text:
in one place and one property has been very
important to me. And also getting a search,

153.35.text:
you know, comprehensiveness. And also recency.
I mean, things that happened only a minute

157.04.text:
ago, you can find now. So that's been big.
Our advertising and our publishers--The partnerships

162.63.text:
that we have--partnerships with advertisers
right now is huge. I mean, we're supporting,

167.51.text:
I think, an entire Web ecosystem, and I'm
very proud of that. Data centers, you know,

172.06.text:
when I seen an aerial picture of what our
data center looks like right now and, you

177.51.text:
know, the networks that went into it, the
technology that went into it, I'm very proud

180.67.text:
of those. But there's also other things. Small
properties. You know, things like speech recognition

186.85.text:
and translation have been huge, and I think
are gonna make a worldwide impact. And, of

191.89.text:
course, applications, which is an area--He
made me put that into the list. No, I really--

197.17.text:
>> GIROUARD: Save the best for last.
>> EUSTACE: No, I really feel like right now

199.26.text:
we're at a stage, now, where I think we can
lower the barrier of entry to corporations

206.75.text:
and stuff. We can change the economics. We
can apply a lot of the research and development

212.77.text:
efforts that we've had on a much larger scale.
And I think we can change the economics of

219.26.text:
the industry. So I'm really looking forward
to that as well.

221.21.text:
>> GIROUARD: Great. Great stuff. Maybe I'll
just do one question of each, and then we'll

223.36.text:
go to the audience. Vint's obviously been
involved in the development of the Internet

229.60.text:
for a long time and has done a lot of work
with the U.S. Government over the years. One

233.60.text:
of the notions that this group here hears
about a lot, and I'm just interested in your

237.33.text:
perspective, is the notion of a private cloud.
What's the public cloud, what's the private

242.15.text:
cloud? Is this a semantic debate, or is there
some substance to it?

246.02.text:
>> CERF: Well, first of all, I have to tell
you that coming on after that performance

251.07.text:
from The Onion is tough. I think it is not
a semantic difference. Private clouds are

258.04.text:
just as reasonable as private Internets. Networks
that use the technology of Internet, but don't

262.67.text:
go outside and interconnect with the rest
of the world. So companies that make clouds

267.37.text:
for other companies--I think of IBM, for example--are
making things that are tools for those companies

274.62.text:
to use. The clouds that we make here are tools
for people to use. They're much more broadly

280.25.text:
accessible because of the fact that they're
reachable through the public Internet. So

284.79.text:
I don't see those as in conflict with each
other. In fact, one of the things that you

289.68.text:
didn't ask, but I'm going to answer anyway,
like every good graduate student does--you

293.56.text:
adapt the question until you can answer it--is
that inter-cloud interaction is something

300.23.text:
that is still very much in a formative stage.
If anyone is thinking about "How do I get

306.56.text:
my data out after I put it in? How do I move
it from one cloud to another?" There is no

312.53.text:
vocabulary right now for cloud A to say, "Please
move this data to cloud B." It's like we were

320.16.text:
in 1973 with the Internet. There were networks--
they were proprietary. The S&A network didn't

326.12.text:
interact in any convenient way with DECnet
or with Hewlett-Packard's network. The Internet

331.95.text:
came along and said, "We can make a non-proprietary
way of allowing all these nets to interact."

336.61.text:
I think we're at the same point in 2010 where
we were in 1973 when it comes to intercloud

342.62.text:
interactions. Just to add one more point,
imagine that you have data in cloud A, and

347.03.text:
it's protected. It's access-controlled. You've
gone to a lot of trouble to do that. The question

351.93.text:
then is, if I do want to move the data to
cloud B, how do I move the metadata along

355.82.text:
with it so that it's correctly understood
and interpreted as equivalent access control?

362.86.text:
So there are a number of different organizations
pursuing questions about intercloud interaction.

367.59.text:
It's a very rich area for exploration, and
I don't think there are a whole lot of solid

372.43.text:
answers yet.
>> GIROUARD: Great. Thanks, Vint. A question

376.06.text:
for Jeff. And just by way of context, Jeff
has been responsible for quite some time for

380.34.text:
the engineering work around Google apps as
well as Google's ad systems and numerous other

385.15.text:
types of systems within Google. But I want
to ask Jeff--I mean, Google's known for, you

389.62.text:
know, launch quickly, iterate often, that
type of approach towards making innovation

395.59.text:
happen and happen very quickly. What does
Google have to do to reconcile that with the

400.33.text:
needs of a large enterprise, which obviously
needs something that's more predictable, where

405.26.text:
it has more of a tried and true--a more diverse
user base, perhaps, that

408.13.text:
>> HUBER: Sure. So we've done our best to
combine the best of both. We do have the foundation

416.39.text:
of starting with very large-scale consumer
services, where we've already made the capital

421.62.text:
investment. We have a great user experience.
There's consumer understanding of what those

426.70.text:
products are, how they work. There's a lot
of pull in the organization. You heard that

430.50.text:
some in the CIO panel, where a lot of the
users already are enthusiasts. Active users

436.78.text:
already know how to use these products. So
both the adoption and training and a lot of

441.06.text:
the things are much less of an issue. That
said, there are very notable differences between

446.48.text:
the two use cases. So we've done a lot of
work on just prioritizing the feature work

451.71.text:
of what are the kind of capabilities you need
in the Enterprise. You know, some of just

456.26.text:
the very tactical things, like delegation
of accounts and a calendar being able to support

461.76.text:
resources, things like that. That said, when
we get into those requirements, we often see

467.62.text:
that those are very common with enthusiasts
or power-user consumer cases. So we do think

472.80.text:
that the model of having a single platform
driving that continues to make a lot of sense.

478.84.text:
We've accelerated some of our investments
around reliability and security, which are

483.37.text:
topics that very near and dear to the Enterprise
heart. But again, we see parallels of that

489.00.text:
into the consumer world, where the kind of
things that we've done around Gmail with default

493.61.text:
https for wireless users has been a big boon
of having log-in history information and location

502.40.text:
available and accessible. They are important
for the Enterprise, but important for consumer

506.96.text:
users as well. And then another area for the
Enterprise that's been particularly important

513.23.text:
is being able to support--scalably support
an organization. So building out the APIs

519.14.text:
that you need to be able to transition and
manage. You have very large user bases. Having

524.69.text:
the ability to provision 20,000 accounts or
30,000 accounts when you're doing the weekend

529.96.text:
migration from one place to another. And then
all of the inner operation that you need,

536.05.text:
with the existing infrastructure that you
have--being able to sync to different devices,

539.64.text:
being able to migrate from one platform to
another are some of the incremental things

545.22.text:
that we've had to prioritize. But that foundation
of having products that scale, that have a

552.50.text:
user experience where there's consumer understanding
and consumer demand, we continue to be very

557.37.text:
excited about it.
>> GIROUARD: All righty. Thanks, Jeff. Let's

559.85.text:
go to the first question from the audience.
>> ROSS: Hi, gentlemen, this is Doug Ross,

564.29.text:
Western & Southern Financial Group. A question
really for all of you. We've seen some changes

570.94.text:
with respect to network neutrality with some
decisions over the last couple of weeks. And,

576.43.text:
Dr. Cerf, I know you've been heavily involved
with network neutrality. I'm interested in

581.74.text:
what's your take on the FCC and network neutrality
in general and your relationships with the

588.70.text:
various carriers. Thank you.
>> CERF: So first of all--let me take the

593.34.text:
last part first. In a sense, we are very dependent
on carriers all around the world, because

598.93.text:
that's how users get to our products and services.
So maintaining a working relationship with

605.55.text:
them is important to us. With regard to net
neutrality, the term itself has been vastly

611.39.text:
distorted by the various debates and the biases
that people have regarding oversight of network

618.54.text:
operation. The point that I'd like to emphasize
is that our concern has been couched in terms

624.33.text:
of anti-competitive behavior. The possibility
that an entity that controls broadband access

630.47.text:
to the Internet in general might also interfere,
in some fashion, with the choice of users

637.69.text:
to get access to any service and any product
and any application anywhere on the Internet

642.79.text:
in the interests of the company that's controlling
that broadband access. And so our biggest

647.29.text:
concern is not that all packets are treated
identically. We know that doesn't make sense.

651.97.text:
It's not that you shouldn't have to pay more
if you consume more resources--that's not

656.18.text:
net neutrality. Net neutrality has to do with
assuring that there's a level playing field

661.04.text:
so that companies like Google, Yahoo!, and
others that provide services to consumers

667.39.text:
will have equal opportunity for the consumers
to reach their products. There's a built-in,

673.50.text:
inherent potential-- what I would say conflict
of interest. If you're in the business of

679.33.text:
delivering video for a fee, but you are also
supplying broadband access to the Internet,

685.33.text:
it's conceivable that you would want to limit
the competitors from delivering their video

691.45.text:
in an equally facilitated way. I'm not saying
anybody's doing that, but the concern is there

698.55.text:
because there isn't a great deal of choice
for users to pick among the various broadband

702.68.text:
providers. With regard to the most recent
decision--I'm just an engineer and not an

708.17.text:
attorney, but the way I've interpreted this
is that the court said that the Title 1 place,

715.02.text:
where Internet is now located for, let me
call it regulatory purposes, didn't give the

720.93.text:
FCC, in the court's view, adequate leverage
to cite Comcast for its interference with,

731.22.text:
in particular, BitTorrent traffic. I think
that the side effect of that may be to drive

737.11.text:
the FCC towards relabeling Internet service
into, for example, Title 2, which is communications

745.97.text:
services. As an engineer, I have felt very
strongly that the Internet does have a layered

751.50.text:
structure. It does have a communications component.
That communications component should be equally

757.21.text:
accessible to everyone. And in the past, when
communications and Internet services were

762.81.text:
in Title 2, the common carriage rules applied.
And when you offered access to communications

770.85.text:
services, you had to do so on an equal basis
to everyone, equal terms and conditions. So

777.60.text:
I think that a return to that should not be
accompanied, however, with a return to all

783.22.text:
of strictures and regulatory structures of
Title 2. You know, the telephony-related things

789.01.text:
don't necessarily have to apply. So the trick
for the FCC will be to figure out whether

793.88.text:
it can make such a move and do so in a way
that limits the range of regulatory oversight

801.16.text:
that it chooses to exercise over a reclassified
Internet.

807.12.text:
>> GIROUARD: Thanks, Vint. Next question.
>> STANTLEY: Andrew Stantley, from MWV. Vint,

813.23.text:
specifically, and then to the whole panel.
What do you see as the greatest challenge

816.75.text:
from a protocol perspective? So much of what
you guys do are based off of the protocols

820.46.text:
that came out in the '70s, '80s, and '90s.
>> CERF: Yeah.

822.65.text:
>> STANTLEY: Where do you see your next focus
being? Specifically to Vint, and then to the

827.10.text:
panel--how is Google going to continue to
be the thought leader that gives us access

830.53.text:
to these great technologies in a way that
enterprises can easily consume them?

834.31.text:
>> CERF: So my part of the answer is that
scaling, of course, is still a major issue.

838.99.text:
IPv6 is utterly critical, and I'm so proud
of Google for having implemented IPv6 in a

844.41.text:
timely way, ahead of many others. We're going
to run out of the v4 address space in the

849.54.text:
middle of 2011 or sooner. There are very few
slash-A blocks that are left. And I think

855.28.text:
that's a really important message for each
one of you who cares to make sure that your

860.30.text:
participation in an expanding Internet will
continue. You need to implement v6 in parallel

865.24.text:
with v4, and you need to ask your ISPs to
do that. On the more general basis, I see

870.36.text:
some huge opportunities for Internet to expand
into wireless modes of operation--satellite-based

875.64.text:
operation, which, up till now, it has not
exploited. When you transmit over the radio,

881.65.text:
you have the possibility of delivering the
same thing to multiple parties. The Internet

885.66.text:
protocols don't take advantage of that. They
take broadcast media and turn them into point-to-point

890.07.text:
links. And in some sense, that is a pity,
because there are some very useful things

894.58.text:
you can imagine doing with a satellite raining
Internet packets down on 100 million receivers

899.66.text:
for people who are interested in receiving
something in common, like a new update of

903.52.text:
software. So I think scaling, and the ability
to make better use of radio-based resources

911.12.text:
are major areas for development. The higher-level
applications, though--identity, authentication...the

917.44.text:
ability to know with whom you're transacting
is another place where I anticipate a great

921.78.text:
deal of important work.
>> EUSTACE: We also have a big group working

927.11.text:
on HTML5. We think that's a place where the
standards are really gonna make a big difference,

932.39.text:
because, you know, you're all aware of Internet-delivered
applications, and you know how important it

937.79.text:
is to make that experience as fast and as
interactive as you might see in other kinds

943.19.text:
of mediums, like direct applications. And
that's an area where we're spending a lot

947.91.text:
of time and a lot of effort and lot of engineering
resources.

950.42.text:
>> GIROUARD: I'm gonna just interject a question,
since you brought up HTML5. One of the interesting

955.76.text:
things that's happening, I'd love to hear
any of your perspectives on, is in the mobile

960.21.text:
world, in a certain way, though HTML5 obviously
is important and most of the mobile-platform

966.73.text:
providers are talking about it, there's also
a re-emergence, in a certain way, of traditionally

971.89.text:
installed applications. And in some sense,
this feels like we're taking a step back,

977.64.text:
but I would appreciate your perspectives on
the browser as the platform versus native

984.11.text:
applications, and where all that might go.
>> HUBER: Start.

987.07.text:
>> EUSTACE: So, you know, my view is that,
you know, there's always been this application

992.30.text:
versus the Web, you know, that goes back,
you know, for, you know, as long as I've been

996.50.text:
in the industry, practically. And there's
always a gap, right, between what an individual

1002.51.text:
native application can do, given all the resources
it has, and what a web-delivered application

1009.39.text:
can do. I think the real interesting thing
now is that application-delivered-- applications

1018.60.text:
that are delivered as applications are now
accessing the Internet. So there's a blending

1023.04.text:
going on, where it's not just a stand-alone
application anymore. They're using Internet

1028.66.text:
as a tool to deliver data. And the same thing
on the Internet. You get this fantastic ability

1034.37.text:
to basically run across browsers and things
like that. You can deliver any application

1037.96.text:
that you want. You don't have to build one
for this client and this client and this client

1041.72.text:
and this client and this client. So there's
a big opportunity between those two. But right

1047.91.text:
now I think it's fair to say there's still
a gap between what you can deliver in an application,

1052.55.text:
in terms of interactivity and other kinds
of things, versus what HTML5 can do right

1057.53.text:
now. And obviously you get lots of interoperability
and things like that. So the real key is how

1064.26.text:
to close that gap. And by the way, that gap
used to be like this. You know, it's gotten

1068.55.text:
like this. Now that applications are accessing
the Internet, it's like this. But there's

1073.20.text:
no-- You know, there's no reason that an Internet-delivered
application cannot be as rich and as graphical

1081.05.text:
and as interactive and all that as one that
you actually shrink-wrap and have to go across

1085.39.text:
five things. But I think it's fair to say
right now there's a gap, and we have to address

1090.57.text:
that gap, which is why HTML5 is so important
to us.

1093.38.text:
>> HUBER: Yeah, and just echoing some of the
comments of this morning. I think it was Jeffrey

1097.48.text:
Moore that mentioned that there is gonna be
a proliferation of different devices. And

1101.36.text:
the app model doesn't scale well across different
devices. The HTML5, the Web model, does very

1106.35.text:
well. So as a developer, as we push, and as
the HTML5 evolves and becomes more and more

1114.81.text:
rich so that that gap between what you can
do in an HTML5 app and a, "native app," becomes

1119.69.text:
smaller. Then you have the choice of do you
want to develop once and get a lot of benefit,

1123.85.text:
or do you want to have to develop uniquely
an app for each and every platform?

1128.13.text:
>> EUSTACE: One thing that we're also doing
is, there's a group that's working on something

1133.08.text:
called Native Client. And Native Client, basically,
is a way to take code, put it into a sandbox,

1139.14.text:
actually instrument to make sure that it can't
get to any of the other things. So protect

1142.92.text:
it, but run at native speeds. And so that's
an example of when, you know, one side of

1147.66.text:
technology works well, and everybody adopts
it, that will raise the bar on what a Web-delivered

1153.45.text:
application can do. So it's pretty exciting.
>> CERF: So I wonder if I could add a couple

1157.36.text:
of thoughts. First of all, this "Internet
of things" is a term that's popped up now

1160.86.text:
and then, and I'm a big fan of putting more
things on the network. The smart grid is another

1166.14.text:
avenue along those lines. I'm frankly excited
about the fact that the Internet manages to

1172.53.text:
serve as this variety of things, whether it's
Web-based, or it's based on a native mode

1177.86.text:
direct access to Internet functionality. I
actually hope that we are able to retain that

1184.81.text:
breadth of operation because it opens up so
many innovative opportunities. It may be that

1190.42.text:
our future is not strictly Web. It may be
there are other kinds of platforms that we

1195.29.text:
will want to have available to us in the Internet.
One thing I would note is as the speeds go

1201.29.text:
up at the edges of the Net, whether it's for
mobile or for dedicated facilities, that the

1206.14.text:
ability to download a piece of software within
the context of a Web browser becomes easier

1211.33.text:
and easier. And as storage costs go down,
it becomes less and less painful to, literally,

1216.03.text:
in real time, download a piece of software
and then run it. So that the dynamics--the

1220.64.text:
ability to adapt, the ability to bring up
new applications quickly becomes very attractive.

1225.73.text:
And the sandbox, which Alan mentioned, is
utterly critical, because you don't want these

1231.39.text:
random applications to have unlicensed access,
so to speak, to all of the resources of the

1236.40.text:
platform. Only those that are appropriate.
>> GIROUARD: Okay, let's go--We'll go here,

1241.32.text:
and then over here.
>> OLIVER: Hi, my name is Oliver. I work for

1244.49.text:
Soluciones Avion in Chile. And as you said
earlier, Dave, competition is good. And we

1251.80.text:
represent Google, and we sell Google apps
throughout all Latin America. And one of the

1255.71.text:
things that we are seeing a lot, at least
in Latin America, is the question on clients

1259.88.text:
that are, you know, seeing Exchange and seeing
Google apps, and they're questioning us a

1265.28.text:
lot about Google Voice and Unified Communications.
So what about the future? What's coming up

1271.56.text:
on that stage?
>> GIROUARD: I'm not sure I'm allowed to answer,

1275.36.text:
'cause I'm the moderator. But I don't know,
can we break the rules?

1277.99.text:
>> HUBER: Go for it!
>> GIROUARD: Look, our goal is actually to

1284.04.text:
be able to unlock all of Google's sort of
candy story of capabilities within Google

1288.38.text:
apps. And we haven't done that yet. And we
haven't done that, because, frankly, a very

1292.93.text:
pragmatic decision we made a few years ago,
which kind of put Google apps in a different

1297.07.text:
world than the consumer apps. We are working
on dissolving that. We want to make sure you

1302.11.text:
have access to every Google service you want
to within your business and have choices about

1306.09.text:
which ones make sense for you. So when you
think about things like Google Voice and Blogger

1311.42.text:
and the many, many other apps and services
that Google has, it is absolutely our goal

1315.78.text:
to make them available to everybody. And you're
gonna see more and more of that through this

1319.65.text:
year. So that's kind of the short version.
We hear you--we hear it constantly. So we're

1324.26.text:
acutely aware that we need to do better on
this sooner.

1327.24.text:
>> HUBER: Good answer, mister moderator.
>> GIROUARD: Okay, back to form. Mister Moderator

1332.09.text:
now. Yes?
>> WARREN: Hi, I'm Jeremy Warren, from the

1334.72.text:
Department of Justice. I just had a question
about the impact of explicitly declared semantics

1340.91.text:
and the search going forward. I know that
Google's always taken a very implicit semantic

1346.03.text:
approach, partially because you learn so much
from what your users are asking and what they're

1350.42.text:
doing and the kind of information that's out
there. But either with RDF or with the rise

1357.21.text:
of the cloud, and if you're seeing more structured
data being stored in the cloud, does the way

1361.94.text:
that search needs to happen, with regards
to explicit semantics, change in the future?

1367.19.text:
>> CERF: Well, one immediate reaction is that
there's--just like there's dark matter and

1371.99.text:
dark energy in the universe-- we don't quite
understand what it is--there's a huge amount

1375.97.text:
of dark information in the Net that you don't
see with the normal calling mechanisms. And

1381.03.text:
finding a way to make those more explicit,
more visible, more discoverable without having

1385.59.text:
to send a robot out to ask a million questions
of each database in order to generate HTML

1390.39.text:
that you can index is, in my opinion, anyway,
a very important avenue for exploration. I'd

1397.24.text:
be curious to see what you two guys think
about that.

1398.92.text:
>> HUBER: Yeah, I mean, ultimately our goal
is to organize the rules of information, make

1404.82.text:
it universally accessible and useful. There's
an awful lot of information out there that

1407.78.text:
is either implicitly or explicitly structured
that the more we can intuit that, understand

1413.84.text:
that, the better results that we can provide.
So some of that is run explicitly structured

1418.79.text:
information. Things like we do recognize and
support microformats and are exposing some

1423.18.text:
of that in the search results and search snippets
across some of the different data types we

1429.10.text:
include in universal search. There is more
structure around things like product search,

1432.76.text:
so we recognize product prices and price ranges
and brands and things like that. And then

1439.58.text:
we've had other efforts around public data,
where we've had some announcements over the

1444.55.text:
last quarter where we were taking government-provided
information and making it much more accessible

1450.40.text:
and visualizable. So those are some examples
of recognizing the role of implicit and explicit

1457.24.text:
structure.
>> EUSTACE: Yeah, the difficulty with the

1461.63.text:
explicit structure is getting people to actually
do it and then to keep it updated all the

1467.28.text:
time. I mean, the beauty of the Web and the
Web pages is you actually see it. So if there's

1471.57.text:
a mistake, you'll actually know about it.
And therefore, anything that we can do implicitly

1478.29.text:
is much better. If we can, basically, extract
structure from unstructured Web pages, it's

1482.92.text:
much easier for us. We have, obviously, machine
learning and algorithms and other things.

1487.67.text:
But fundamentally, the goal has to be to understand
structure. And to the extent where that's

1492.96.text:
not possible, we've done things like Google
Base and other things that allow you to load

1498.14.text:
in lots of data. I do think getting more people
to load in more data and actually data that

1504.63.text:
can be tagged, updated all the time so that
you can start composing data in interesting

1509.23.text:
ways on the Web is something that we're definitely
interested in, because it will basically enable

1515.37.text:
us to do a lot of things that we could not
do anyway. But our basic bias is toward implicit

1521.93.text:
rather than explicit, because it's just so
hard to get people to tag everything, you

1526.41.text:
know. And then it's fine to get 'em tagged
at once, but to get 'em to basically maintain

1529.57.text:
that over long periods of time is quite difficult.
>> GIROUARD: Okay.

1534.60.text:
>> CAPP: Hi, I'm Kevin Capp, with the town
of Castle Rock. And we're excited to partner

1539.55.text:
with Google on your Fiber To the Home network.
I'm sure we're the top competitor, so I'm

1546.12.text:
wondering if you could just talk a little
bit about that project and how it maybe ties

1552.89.text:
into other things you're talking about today.
>> CERF: Well, I have a little bit that I

1558.71.text:
can add to this. You understand that this
project is, at least as I view it, is an experiment

1564.19.text:
to figure out what it takes to actually deliver
a gigabit per second to a residential user.

1571.21.text:
We know in other parts of the world, this
has already been done. In Japan, there are

1575.36.text:
a number of places where you can get gigabit
service for whatever, 8,700 yen a month. Which

1579.78.text:
made me want to move to Kyoto not too long
ago. The real question, though, is what does

1584.69.text:
it actually take, technologically--what does
it cost? What kind of technologies and processes

1590.84.text:
are needed in order to not only deliver that
kind of capacity, but to maintain it and operate

1595.46.text:
it? So unless Alan tells me differently, I
don't believe that our business model is to

1600.32.text:
go and replicate that all over the world so
that everybody gets a Google-provided gigabit,

1605.12.text:
but rather to understand and be able to articulate
what it takes to do that. We get told by many

1612.66.text:
others about the costs and difficulties, and
I think this is one way for us to verify,

1618.62.text:
maybe even discover or suggest ways of doing
it that might be more effective. So, Alan,

1623.47.text:
if I mis-got that, you might want to respond.
>> EUSTACE: No, I think that's very accurate.

1627.30.text:
If you look back in our history, we did wireless
for Mountain View. We were gonna do it for

1632.17.text:
San Francisco at one point. But the purpose
was not to roll out wireless all over the

1636.47.text:
world. It was to understand the economics
of it, understand the issues. And we could

1640.33.text:
actually push forward, you know, some of the
ideas that we had into other places. And I

1647.01.text:
think wireless has rolled out pretty substantially
over that period of time. This is a case where,

1654.26.text:
you know--You can't learn about some things
on paper. You know, I don't care how great

1658.78.text:
you're business analysts are. Maybe you've
got better business analysts than we do, but,

1664.22.text:
you know, sometimes you have to just build
it and then understand what the issues are.

1667.69.text:
I mean, I know there's--And that's the same
way that we do in our applications. Sometimes

1674.22.text:
we just ship it and find out what the result
is, you know. And to find out, you know, whether

1679.50.text:
this feature or this feature. I remember in
news, there was a case where we had two features.

1683.86.text:
Both of them were--You know, we argued about
it back and forth for a very long time about

1687.93.text:
which one was better. The ship date actually
made it so neither of them got shipped. But

1692.88.text:
99 people out of 100 asked for feature A,
and none of 'em--You know, one person asked

1698.03.text:
for feature B. So we knew, after we shipped
the product, basically what consumers really

1702.90.text:
wanted. And I think in this case there's business-model
issues, there's, you know, trenching issues.

1707.79.text:
I now, for the first time, know exactly what
the cost model looks like for this. I know

1711.98.text:
exactly what segments are the issue in terms
of cost. I know about micro-trenching. I know

1716.98.text:
about lots of things that we as a company
didn't know about before. And I feel like

1721.17.text:
that's important for us if we're gonna interact
with that business.

1724.28.text:
>> GIROUARD: Okay, maybe just one more from
me, and if there's one more in the audience

1728.38.text:
after, we can-- We're almost done here. But
one of the discussion topics that keeps coming

1733.64.text:
back is trust. In the audience, there are
a lot of people, uh, have a lot of obligations.

1739.94.text:
And there's a governance model, and they have
a lot of responsibilities to take care of

1744.07.text:
data, take care of the services to their employees.
So what I think is a very fair question to

1748.06.text:
ask, and I'll turn it over to any of you--maybe
start with Jeff--is one of the things Google

1751.88.text:
is doing to earn the trust of CIOs and other
IT professionals in order for them to have

1758.38.text:
a good sense of using Google for mission-critical
services.

1760.90.text:
>> HUBER: Sure. Um, I think there's--First,
there's a baseline of all of the investments,

1767.29.text:
and I touched on some of this earlier, the
investments we're making around reliability

1770.98.text:
of service and security that are just fundamental.
Those are ongoing investments that we're making,

1776.70.text:
and we're continuing to innovate and invest
in the infrastructure to make those better

1780.41.text:
and better. And complementing those, we have
gone through processes that document exactly

1786.79.text:
what we're doing and how we're doing it. Things
like SAS 70 certification, FISMA certification

1792.68.text:
so that, with standards, bodies, and models
that you recognize we can confirm what we're

1798.81.text:
doing. We also recently heard about the Department
of Integrity having a new certification. Just

1805.28.text:
heard about it. We're pretty sure we're gonna
get a perfect 6.0 there. But the more fundamental

1813.13.text:
or structural things that we're doing are
around, first, just our commitment to openness.

1820.78.text:
We try, in all of our systems, to adhere to
open protocols and have exchange--or the ability

1827.03.text:
to export your data, review your data as your
data and not something that we're trying to

1832.06.text:
capture and keep. And part of that is philosophical
of just the Google way of doing business.

1837.34.text:
But also, pragmatically, it keeps us honest
and forces us to continue innovating and providing

1843.60.text:
a great service, because we know that if we
ever let you down, there is nothing locking

1848.04.text:
you in. You can leave at any time. So we have
a built-in incentive there to continue to

1854.25.text:
innovate and do great things with the product.
We've kind of institutionalized that into

1858.95.text:
an effort we that we call Data Liberation.
If you do a search for Google Data Liberation,

1862.64.text:
you can find out a lot more about it. It's
an ongoing commitment that we have. The other

1867.28.text:
is around transparency of--per some of the
discussion of the CIO panel, no organization

1873.96.text:
is going to be perfect and have 100% reliable
availability of services. We're not going

1880.89.text:
to deliver that. We are going to be very,
very good, but when we fall down, we're gonna

1884.59.text:
make sure that that information is transparently
available, visible to you. You know the status

1889.69.text:
of what we're doing to fix things, and you
know the follow-up steps that we're taking

1893.63.text:
to correct things. And that can be seen in
the apps status dashboard. If you go to www.google.com/appsstatus,

1901.78.text:
you can see the performance history of all
of our products since that feature was rolled

1906.81.text:
out a couple of quarters ago.
>> EUSTACE: Just let me add one other thing

1910.68.text:
that I can guarantee you is that we're using
our own products internally. And I think that's

1916.00.text:
a big win from your point of view. We're betting
our own company on our products. And we don't

1922.97.text:
get any special treatment, I guarantee. Just
to let you know the history, we used to actually

1928.65.text:
have Gmail as a separate application inside
the company. And, you know, there was everybody

1933.69.text:
else's Gmail, and there was the company's
Gmail. And I still remember the meeting with

1937.18.text:
Larry when we talked about this. And the people
were basically saying, "Well, what happens?

1942.71.text:
You know, if we basically use the Gmail that
everybody else is using, somebody might see

1946.37.text:
our data." And Larry says, "Yeah. Yeah, we're
trying to convince people to use our data."

1952.68.text:
He goes, "Well, these are companies." And
Larry looks at me and says, "You mean my personal

1958.01.text:
data is more important than some company data?"
And, you know, the person was just dumbfounded.

1963.19.text:
It's the same data. It's the same thing. Privacy
is exactly the same problem. You know, trust

1968.75.text:
is exactly the same problem. It's the same
problem. And so our data--And since that meeting,

1973.71.text:
we've combined data centers. There's no special
servers. You know, we are treated just like

1978.31.text:
any other application inside of Gmail. And
the same thing with our apps. We use them,

1983.08.text:
we dog food 'em, we try everything out ourselves.
I sent a message this morning to Orris on

1987.32.text:
a bug that's driving me crazy, you know. And
I'm sure he's listening to me. So I think

1993.07.text:
that's the other thing is that we're not just
selling you something we don't use. We're

1997.52.text:
selling you something that we believe in as
a product.

1999.72.text:
>> HUBER: We're living it.
>> EUSTACE: And we're living it every day.

2002.41.text:
And you can guarantee that there's 20,000
advocates right now for the same kind of changes

2008.97.text:
that you're trying to get us to make inside
the company.

2011.95.text:
>> GIROUARD: The last thing I'll say, just
in closing, I think "advocates" is probably

2014.74.text:
the most polite way they've ever described,
because Google, you know, 20,000 employees,

2021.27.text:
probably almost half of which are engineers,
are amongst the most demanding users of any

2025.57.text:
technology in the world. So I assure you that
the conversations which are usually polite

2031.58.text:
are very to the point about who thinks our
products ought to do better. And we're working

2035.92.text:
very hard at it. So we're miraculously on
time. I think Quentin's gonna come back up.

2040.67.text:
And we're almost done for the morning. Thank
you, gentlemen. It was great to have you here.

2044.27.text:
>> CERF: Okay. Thanks, everybody.
>> GIROUARD: Way to go. See you later.

2057.18.text:
>> HARDY: All right, well, just before, Jeff
Huber told me there's a miracul--Um, Jeff,

2064.86.text:
is there a miraculous new app--We're breaking
for lunch now. And Google was gonna get ready

2070.95.text:
to announce a way to feed everybody watching
the Webcast as well. Has that panned out?

2075.82.text:
No, it's not ready. "Foodle," it was called.
Okay, so that's--I'm sorry, you guys watching,

2081.00.text:
you'll have to take care of yourselves for
lunch. Those of you here in the room, lunch

2084.67.text:
is being served out in the heated tents. These
guys really can cook. You want to stay. And

2089.92.text:
there is limited seating as well back behind
the curtains, but I encourage you to go out

2094.15.text:
to the heated tents. Also, there is demo stations
outside where you can work and play with the
